description:
I hate to share this -- because I really don't want this place to become a crowded spot, especially around lunch time -- but if you have ten bucks, you'll get a large meal and then some. Who am I kidding -- you'll get lunch, with leftovers for dinner, and maybe enough for lunch the next day. 

The food is fresh, its always cooked well and the service is always good (there's just this one nice lady who always greets me with "Welcome back. The usual?" -- then in a few minutes, my order appears) - I'm kind of addicted to this place, so I need to visit maybe once a week. They're like the neighborhood "Claim Jumper" for Chinese food. Do you remember when Claim Jumper used to serve large portions of nearly everything? That's Punjab.

Alright, I'm done with Yelp for the day. I've got some Saturday stuff to do.
author: John A.

description:
Punjab seems like such a misplaced random shop that I feel like it pushes away potential customers with it's generic signs but it's pretty damn amazing for where it is at, how good it taste, and how much it cost.

First of all, it's a Chinese / Vietnamese restaurant. Nothing Indian whatsoever, don't get confused. But the poor-ish naming convention for an Asian restaurant just makes this place all the more authentic to me.

Service
And I feel like this place is the real deal, the service is what you'd expect, a little more rude, but they are actually just no fuss, they are quick to take your order and deliver your meal.

Food
I've tried the Pho, I've tried the Chinese, and I've tried their Vietnamese sandwiches, all of them pass the price-food ratio test for me. As someone who is more value oriented with food, this place hits the sweet spot!

The restaurant seems very home-y for me, the waiters all seem to get along (family-run?) they seem to have a good amount of regulars. It's not going to be the best-tasting chinese or vietnamese food or the cleanest but it's pretty damn great for what it is.

*Ordering take-out is also a breeze. Your order will be ready in 10-15min.
author: Mike L.

description: Great food, luv this spot  we had a big group of 30+.. the customer service was top notch for 1 person doing everything..
author: Antonio V.

description: Nothing like a big bowl of pho to help a hangover! I recently discovered this place after living down the street for a year. The menu doesn't make sense and neither does the name but it works. The combination pho is a must try.
author: Taylor H.

description: The best chinese-american restaurant in the neighborhood. Most dishes can be made vegan with tofu. The lunch special is a great value.
author: W T.

description: Cheap and pretty tasty. I was pleasantly surprised by the extensive menu and quality of the pho and black bean cod dishes that we ordered. Exterior looked odd to me, so I had avoided the place for a while, thinking it was just another greasy Chinese takeout spot, but now I'll definitely be back!
author: Cassie X.

description: My go-to neighborhood restaurant! Somehow the "Chinese-American" restaurant with an Indian name serves the best pho within walking distance of my house. For just over $8, this is a rare gem in San Francisco. There's always somewhere to sit so it's perfect for a quick last minute meal. In such a pretentious city with average food with fancy names costing you and arm and a leg, this place is such a relief!
author: Sara M.

description: This is my favorite place to have soup and Chinese food! This place has been around for a long time.
author: Mickey M.

description:
Do you want a tasty $8.41 lunch, with tax? Heck, a Mission super burrito these days will cost you more than that. Look no further than Punjab: the restaurant that has zero Indian food, but some solid Chinese-American, Vietnamese, and American, as in burger and fries American. I've gone multiple times for lunch and it simply cannot be beat for the amount, quality, and price of the food. 

On my most recent visit, it was a cold and rainy day, and I gave in to an ultimate comfort food: sesame chicken. It was utterly fantastic. Guys,

DO NOT SLEEP ON THE SESAME CHICKEN. 

It was the paragon of this delicious fusion dish: crispy fried chicken in a slightly spicy, sweet sauce, dusted with sesame seeds. And it came with a heap of white rice (brown rice or fried rice costs a dollar extra, and sometimes they're out of brown rice anyway) and some very tasty hot and sour soup that surprisingly had broccoli stems and carrots, but I wasn't mad at it.

Other dishes I've had: 
Pho: broth a little salty, but paired with the five spice chicken (which is perfectly juicy and crispy) it's great
Spicy eggplant: nice, comes with a lot of other vegetables and your choice of protein or tofu
Chow mein with pork: salt and fat bomb, in the best way
Orange chicken: good, but not as good as the sesame chicken

Soups: split pea, wonton, clear broth and veg, hot and sour
author: Anna B.

description: Love their Pho! Is right across the street so one of my favorite place to eat some Mongolian beef as well. My friend loves their Chao Fan (not sure if it's the right spelling). Bad thing that is pretty hard to order via phone cause the server who answers most of the times is a little rough.
author: Edwin M.

description:
As others have already mentioned, Punjab is an unusual restaurant that serves Chinese, Vietnamese, and American food. 

While the owners of this family-owned restaurant are Chinese, their best food may be their Vietnamese dishes. I've had the chicken pho, which is just as good as Thanh Tam II on Valencia and 17th, and the chicken banh mi.

Their Chinese dishes are generally americanized...think chow mein, fried rice, string bean chicken, similar to stuff you can get at Panda Express. Their hot and sour soup, while not authentic, is decent.

Overall, this is a decent three star place. Cheap prices and fast service.
author: Tim X.

description: I always have a great time at Punjab. The place is quiet and spacious yet very inviting. The service is awesome. I made this joint a staple.
author: Leroy L.

description:
I can't tell you how many times I've walked in here hungover and eaten some pho and/or orange chicken and been truly satisfied. Is this restaurant hip? No. Is that okay? YES. This is an affordable, family restaurant with an awesome vibe. It was in an episode of Looking because the interior has a serious feeeeling. Personally, I'll take that true vintage diner feel with odd neon signs over modern hipster decor any day. Also, I've dragged multiple hesitant friends here and they all end up agreeing it's tasty. The pricing is good. The staff is super sweet. Don't expect it to be what it isn't! 

Disclaimer: I've only ever ordered off of and seen others order off of the Asian-style menu. That said, it all tasted good. So, pull up, grab a PBR, and love the Mission for what it is.
author: Sarah X.

description:
I love this place and the cook Felicia! I've been going there for over 3 decades and still love it.
The won ton soup is great and one of my favorites.
The basil chicken is very good too and you can have it as spicy as you'd like.
Her pho is really delicious too!
author: Keith L.

description:
Walked by it now need of something filling and this fit the bill in terms of fast and easy in the area. Sweet lady waitressing.. Great vibe and great garlic eggplant/rice with a side of fries.
Great deal and I was grateful for the unpretentious feel.
author: Melisa P.

description:
A confusingly good restaurant.....An oddly named chinese restaurant that serves solid chinese and vietnamese food.  We ordered beef chow fun, fried calamari, broccoli beef, punjab crispy fried noodles, green beans in garlic sauce, and mandarin chicken (or some sort of chicken dish).  6 hungry people walked in and 6 sleepy, satisfied co-workers left.  Good portions of good chinese food.  While I haven't tried it personally, I've been told the pho and vietnamese sandwiches from here are also very good.


Protip: if you're in a rush (say, on a quick lunch break) you can order your food ahead of time by phone, so its ready when you get there!
author: Alex J.

description:
My second establishment since being in San Fran and dear lord these Yelpers are way too generous. 

Christmas Day, I get it, it's busy, but only one wait staff, one cook, and one that cleans the tables it was a clustercluck. People walking in only to walk out, people who order and walk out, and food that is dear lord, truly Americanized. 

A restaurant that has an Indian name Punjab, resembles an old style American diner, run by a bunch of old Chinese ladies, and serves up Chinese, Vietnamese, and burgers... 

One of these ladies had me hand out forks, napkins, and paper placements to my group after we ordered. And we had sat at a table for 10-15 minutes before being acknowledged. 

We ordered the #3 family style meal, $11.50 per person and it came with wonton soup, chicken fingers, freaky deaky egg rolls, fried rice, beef & broccoli, sweet & sour pork, and mango chicken. 

The wontons were made of pork and Chinese sausage, super salty broth next to undrinkable. The chicken fingers seemed more like fish sticks in texture, the egg rolls, what in the world where in them and why did they look like that? Carrots and some kind of filler... 

The fried rice was okay but it only had shrimp, cha-siu, and eggs, where were the veggies? The beef and broccoli had all the ingredients but didn't taste like the usual beef & broccoli. The sweet & sour pork was tasty but the artificial coloring makes you wonder if Halloween came around again and Count Dracula was there to help season it. Mango chicken was the most flavorful. 

I didn't know Americanized Chinese food could get this bad. Move on people, we ignored all the signs of the name, decor, and service and still didn't walk out, don't make the same mistake.
author: Nancy H.

description: Family owed support the neighborhood and meet the neighborhood here at a great price and great food. Familiar faces yes, music preferred
author: Missy I.

description:
When Chinese, Vietnamese and American military forces confronted each other during the Vietnam War, it must have been the precursor for the menu offered at this strange hybrid of a restaurant. Only this time the battleground was in my belly. I don't know what drew me to come in here on a Tuesday evening except the faint promise of Vietnamese-style short ribs scrawled on a board within view from the sidewalk. I was planning to eat at Tio Chilo's Grill on the next block but gave it a second thought when I thought perhaps I was bypassing another hidden jewel on 24th. No hidden jewel to be found here.

It was perhaps the most dismal dining experience I had since the last time I gave a one-star review. I've only given 16 of them. The interior is quite huge but there was still a sense of clutter about the space with most of the activity happening at the counter with take-out orders or single diners (photo: http://bit.ly/1KW1zbh). I probably should have gone up there, but I decided to take a table next to the window. It turned out to be a big mistake as the waitress ignored me. It took her about five minutes for her to hand me the three-part menu, which wasn't a bad wait, but it took her about fifteen more before she returned. By that time, I had more than enough time to peruse the odd hodgepodge of a menu.

It starts with traditional Cantonese dishes and segues into all-American diner fare with the last page devoted to Vietnamese pho bowls and rice plates. I decided to try the $12.50 Pho Duoi Bo, an oxtail noodle soup, and start with a $4.55 plate of Pork Potstickers. I got them in a leisurely manner, and they were dried out with the crusty bottom just a little too crusty. it came with a sweet plum hoisin sauce that I couldn't quite understand they were serving as an accompaniment (photo: http://bit.ly/1FE59jE). About another twenty minutes elapsed at which point she informs me they were out of the oxtail. Seriously. She waited more than a half-hour to tell me this. She uttered a perfunctory "Sorry" and waited impatiently for me to order a substitute.

Rather spontaneously, I went with the $8.95 Bun Bo Hue, a combination pho with sliced beef shank, brisket, meatballs and steamed pork loaf in a lemongrass broth (photo: http://bit.ly/1HVUhhp). When it finally arrived, I was quite disappointed with the too-salty broth and the overcooked meat. I found the steamed pork loaf virtually inedible. Running true to form, she never did come back to give me the check, so after leaving most of my pho in the bowl, I didn't waste time walking up to the counter to pay. It was a miserable experience and I found myself grappling with the gurgling aftereffects on the bus ride home. Now I know how the Paris Peace Accords must have gone.

FOOD - 1.5 stars...a rather unfortunate combination of blandness and saltiness
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...formica tables in an expansive area
SERVICE - 1 star...a very weak area for them
TOTAL - 1 star...a hodgepodge of dishes none of which worked for me...and what's with the Indian name?
author: Ed U.

description:
No frills, decent one stop shop for all your Chinese/Vietnamese needs (despite the Indian-sounding name). Decently-sized portions, decent Chinese food, and great location on 24th Street which gives it an extra star in my book. The restaurant is huge and has plenty of seating. A lot of people get takeout here, so you'll have plenty of space to yourself. The server is friendly and refills your water OFTEN! 

The food is nothing spectacular, so don't bring a date here. Ambiance is nothing special either -- think casual Chinese/Vietnamese eatery. But it's the only place around that will serve pho, which makes it great for the inevitable horror of a morning post-bar-hopping. 

The Vietnamese food is cooked in a Chinese style. Lemongrass chicken rice plate is actually a kind of lemongrass chicken + string bean stir-fry with rice on the side. Still delicious, but not authentically Vietnamese. 

As long as you don't come here expecting too much, you'll be a happy camper like me!
author: Christine L.

description: I'm giving Punjab 5 stars because of this: it is what it is: a good ole down home American Chinese place. The "new mission" is full of ACI educated chefs  and basic b1tc43s driving out down home places like Punjab. It's a super reliable, dirty, mediocre Chinese place, and I love it for that. The food is "ok" But who cares? Where the hell else can you get $7 Chinese lunch special at 9pm? Where else can you waltz in, gorge yourself on a plate of delectable greasy noodles in semi-privacy? PUNJAB, that's where. Haters gonna hate. Long live Punjab!
author: Matt N.

description: I am a big fan of their sandwiches, never get sick of them. I would like to come back once in a while to try out all the different flavors they offer!
author: Ruby K.

description:
Pretty good. I ordered the spicy basil eggplant dish with beef. Unfortunately, I burned the roof of my mouth during my attempt to inhale the food :(

Nonetheless, it's a decent Chinese restaurant, but nothing spectacular.
author: Cass Y.

description: Always come here to get my hangover won Ton soup. The food is decent and really reasonably priced. Wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but if you are in the neighborhood, it's not a bad option at all.
author: Ross S.

description: I ate here and woke up the next day with straight up heart palpitations. Great food, cheap and lots of it but MSG is clearly high in their food. Beware folks
author: Aklil I.

description:
If you come here expecting a fine dining experience, you will be disappointed.  This is stereotypical Chinese  fast food (and honestly, the food sort of sucks).  I find it refreshing that this has not become a trendy spot with super expensive prices.

Most of the fried food is pretty bad, almost like they're using old oil.  Some of the veggies are of questionable freshness as well.

I give it five stars because it's great hangover food.  Either the pho or fried rice.  Nom nom nom.
author: Chris S.

description: Me and the fam ordered 4 plates of food and a couple drinks which came to about 50, not so bad for 4 people. The issue is she got two of our orders wrong and she is rushing and not providing good customer service. So we get the check and pay it but decide not to leave a tip. Get this, we all walk out and she literally ran outside to stop us and says no tip and we say no sorry about that and she asked two more times then waved her hand in our faces as if she was discussed haha the only thing to be discussed by is the poor quality food that they serve. Don't waste your time or money, like the Jordan Peele GET OUT or she will get you!!
author: Jacob R.

description:
So here you can have Chinese, Vietnamese, and American food. Questionable? Well, I wouldn't blame you. But this is a joint you can swing into for a cheap meal. Portion sizes are decent, and the variety is certainly there, as I mentioned.

I went here for lunch with coworkers and had the scrambled eggs with bbq pork over chow mein. Sure it wasn't amazing, but the greasy Chinese food was exactly what ideas going for.

The Vietnamese rice plate with pork chops looked really great, but lacked the full flair with bì, and their fish sauce wasn't as powerful as I'm used to growing up.

One thing that kind of made me chuckle was when the server brought out my co-worker's phó and pronounced it "foe." Shame on you...

Allegedly, the wait time is supposed to be pretty quick, but for some reason today it took them about half an hour to bring out the simple rice plates. Something to be wary of if you're limited on lunch time!
author: Andrew T.

description: The food is really bad, even if you purposefuly wanted to cook bad you couldn't probably get to the same level. People who hate food and thai kitchen in particular are cooking there. Portions are big and relatively cheap.  Tables are dirtier than roads on 24th. Waiters are fine, not much was expected from them.
author: Lyuba F.

description:
A Chinese restaurant in the Mission with an Indian name, a menu with Vietnamese, Chinese, and American food, and 3.5 stars on Yelp.  My expectations weren't very high walking in.

Inside, it was relatively clean for the Mission, my server was super nice, and they had two signed portraits for when Jackie Chan and Will Smith dined there.  I ordered a #1 Pho, which turned out surprisingly good!  Broth was flavorful, portions were decent, all for only $10.  

I will be coming here again for a quick Pho fix in the future.
author: Matt T.

description:
Who would've thunk that a place called "Punjab" would serve Americanized Chinese food? Someone here with better sleuthing skills than I might have already figured out why... but I'll search for that explanation later.

The food isn't bad. It isn't going to be the most memorable meal you've ever had........ (and I almost can't remember what I even ordered here) but it's just the way you want your weekend fix when you're feeling lazy - cheap, easy, and it fulfills all basic requirements. Food's a bit on the salty side but hey... that's why you order the rice.
author: Asha S.

description:
Having been here 1039411302 times, I'm still equally perplexed as to why this restaurant serves Chinese, Vietnamese, and American food together in the Mission with an Indian name.

That being said, the portions in this place are absolutely terrifyingly large. The combination (punjab) fried rice is my go-to for takeout, and I've also gotten some of the combination plates (e.g. broccoli beef with two pot stickers and rice) before, and they haven't let me down.

What HAS let me down is getting fried chicken wings. There is a difference between 'salt and pepper' chicken wings which is a dish that involves breading chicken wings with a similar mix as the 'salt and pepper' pork chops are breaded with, and 'fried chicken wings' which is a dish that is a (much) worse rendition of kfc. The former is somewhat tolerable (although the salt and pepper mix here is "unique" in that it's different from the way virtually all other chinese restaurants i've tried cook it), but the latter is so inedible that i threw it out.

The quality of the food tends to vary dramatically with the weekends tasting significantly better than the early weekdays in my experience.

Tl;dr: order punjab fried rice, day of the week seems to matter, don't get fried chicken wings.
author: Alexander L.

description:
I come here a lot because it's close to my work and it's a nice go-to place when u just want to sit and have a quick meal. their options vary, most of their options are Chinese-dishes but they have burgers/fries, pho, banh mi, and pork chops/mashed potatoes, so there's a good variety if you want to change it up. 

If you're in a hurry but still want to dine-in, you can order before you come in and just let them know you're going to dine-in, that saves a lot of time.
author: Jason S.

description: Totally quirky, completely odd, and ABSOLUTELY YUMMY!  My husband and I have been saying we should stop in here and try this place because the reviews are so good, and we should have been in much earlier .  The food is very good.  The egg rolls are not like those floppy greased rolls you usually get at a Chinese place...the are fresh and light and very very good.  Very fresh and we were surprisingly please overall.  It's a large place and never a wait.
author: M. R.

description:
So we've been here twice now. It's a nearby walk, was featured in HBO's "Looking," and food there is prepared quickly. On this rainy drizzle day, hot tea was a good start.

I ordered something on a smaller Vietnamese side menu there. It was their Pho Beef Noodle Soup #1: Pho Dac Biet -- Combination: rare steak, brisket, beef meatball, tendon, trite. Once I stirred in the side vegetables, squirted lemon and stirred it all together, the heated broth finished cooking the meat. I liked most everything, except the tendon. Trite was almost like squid, but was worth trying.

Soup bowl was huge. Definitely was full by the 2/3 point. Playing in the background were holiday tunes: everyone from Frank Sinatra to Whitney Houston to Michael Bolton. Not all the best, but 'tis the season.
author: Garett T.

description: I love this place! Food is always great the staff is really friendly. Not to mention the variety of options. Salt and Pepper calamari is THE best! It's my go-to!
author: Jasmine E.

description:
The lady who served us was really sweet. 

I wasn't crazy about the food but as far as quick chinese food goes, it was decent. They seem to use fresh ingredients, too, since I noticed a lady preparing fresh green beans. I can appreciate that! 

Their chow mein noodles are thin. I like the thicker, more moist Chinese chow mein noodles but it did satisfy my craving for Chinese food!
author: Raakin H.

description: I think Punjab Chinese/Vietnamese/American diner is my new go-to hangover spot. Run by efficient nice ladies. Good value. I had a lemongrass pork banh mi. It was great.
author: melissa w.

description:
If you're wondering why:

a) A Chinese restaurant in the Mission is getting 4 stars,
b) A Chinese restaurant in the Mission is named Punjab, or
c) A 4 star Chinese restaurant in the Mission named after an Indian state serves American diner food,

then you've come to the right review.

Punjab is one of those enigmas that leaves you scratching your head when you enter the place, and then rewards you with sweet satisfaction after you've left. I can't imagine that anybody in need of a Chinese food fix would go to this place based on its name and location alone. 

So I'm here to tell you about Punjab's inner beauty and why you should give it a chance as I did when I first moved to the Mission. 

The food is OK. I'll say that off the bat. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. I don't want you to expect earth shattering flavors when you go here. This is not why I like this place. Like I said, the food is decent, but the je ne sais quoi is fantastic. That's right. I haven't quite put my finger on it yet, but I love coming here for reasons unknown. 

Is it because it's the only Chinese restaurant I know that serves Pho? Decent Pho at that. Or maybe it's the server (Serene) who makes you feel at home the minute you step foot inside. She'll know your life story by the end of your meal and you'll know hers. Could it be that they have free mimosas on Sunday for brunch? Or perhaps the fact that you could come here for breakfast and order steak and eggs?

Whatever the reason, I'm S-O-L-D and this is why I keep coming back. It's my go-to resto in a pinch. Prices are cheap, food is pretty good and the staff is warm. And it's 2 blocks from my place (I guess I should have mentioned that before). It does help that it is walking distance from my apartment. A definite plus. Especially in the Mission where there is a scarcity of good Chinese restaurants.

Just for the hell of it, here are a few of my go to items:

Salt and Pepper Pork Chop
Spicy Basil Chicken
Combo #4
King Of Kung Pao
Punjab Fried Rice
Punjab Chow Mein
Wonton Soup

What I won't be ordering again:

Roasted duck
Beef with Brocolli (more like Brocolli with some beef)

And seriously, try the Pho. It's not the best Pho in the world but it might surprise you.

If by your first visit you're not enchanted by this unassuming hole-in-the-wall Chinese/American diner hodgepodge of a restaurant, then you need to have your soul checked. 

4.1 stars
author: Angelo B.

description: The Banh Mi's by the head chef, Felicia, are definitely a hit. On top of that, they are very reasonabl price. Vegan and vegetarian options are available. All ingredients are fresh, as well. This restaurant has great potential in the Mission. Expansive and affordable menu. Great for take out. The pho seems to be also a special here. Comfortable, homey, and well-lit dining area.
author: Kayla F.

description: Amazing food and great service. I have been coming here since my childhood and the food never disappoints. If your looking for some good Chinese food with great service this is the place to be.
author: Mireya R.

description: Been here twice and tried their pho and wonton soup. I was skeptical at first because it has Chinese and Vietnamese food and is called Punjab restaurant, but I have no complaints about the food. The place is a bit dirty, but overall, the food here is great value for the price, and the staff is friendly.
author: Bai L.

description:
Americanized Chinese food.

The portions are good and the service was super quick, and there isn't a lot of people. However the food itself was so-so at least, I guess you would consider it one of the better Chinese options in the Mission, but that isn't really saying much.

If you're looking for a quick cheap bite of Americanized Chinese food, this place is might be the answer.
author: Yao X.

description:
Friday; 8 pm; takeout
Casual attire

Not the best quality food, but it's across the street and we get food to go all the time.

Steamed dumplings: 4 star 
Beef pho: 4 star
Chicken fried rice: 2 star
Honey walnut prawns: 5 star
Steamed pork buns: 3 star

All in all its a great place for big parties and okay food.
author: Rose L.

description:
This might be the best Chinese food I've ever had. Their fried rice is to die for, as is their wonton soup, chow mein, pot stickers and can't forget their amazing pork buns 

The place is very spacious and the staff is always nice and welcoming. Decent prices and good sized portions. One of the few places left in the Mission, this restaurant is truly a gem!
author: Mirna C.

description: I like to eat lunch there when I'm in the neighborhood- good food, good service if Serena the waitress is there, and easy to park. What else do you need, sounds perfect.
author: Carl J.

description: Great local spot for decent chinese food, pho, and bahn mi. Super friendly service. There's a reason this place has been around for a long time.
author: Josh G.

description: The four stars are deceptive! How is that possible! This place is filthy and the meat in the egg roll and fried won ton tasted weird and inedible. The orange chicken had a weird after taste.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Very poor service. We came in to order food to go and waited patiently for our food. After noticing at least five customers getting their food, we asked how long it would take for ours to be done. The waitress looked at us confused and asked which table we were at. We pointed to the table next to the counter she asked us to sit at and said we've been waiting for an hour and the food hasn't been ready. She told us there was only 1 chef and it would be another 20 -30 minutes. That's insane!!! They basically forgot about our order and said wait --- a total of 1.5 hours before we got our order.  Very rude as well.
author: Vicky N.

description: Its ok chinese food for the cheap. Don't expect great customer service or a clean eating enviroment.(Dust, sticky tables and old dinnerware. You get what you pay for.
author: John W.

description:
Here's a little gem in the Mission that you might have missed. Once you're over the shock (or the lack thereof if you're less dramatic and/or normal) of wandering into a prodominantly South American neighborhood and finding an Americanized Chinese restaurant named after an Indian state, you'll settle down and order some food. 

While friends swear by the mandarin chicken and the spicy basil chicken, I personally love the Kung Pao vegetables they serve; it comes with loads of peanuts and crunchy, delicious water-chestnuts among other veggies in a spicy (they ask you for your preferred spice level) sauce. 

Portion size: huge; enough for two meals. How expensive is it? Barely. How good is the service? Great; super-friendly waitresses. How good is the food? Pretty damn good.
author: Divya R.

description:
My trainee and I dined here for lunch. 

Whenever I was needed to work around the area, I've eaten at this cornered restaurant a few times in the past. The restaurant serve Chinese and American cuisines and the food isn't bad at all. Everytime I eat here, I often wondered about the name: "Punjab!"

From this visit earlier this chilly afternoon, my co-worker and I split an order of Salt & Pepper "Spicy" Chicken Wings and Punjab Fried Rice. The $7.00 Punjab Fried Rice dish is known in most Chinese restaurants as the "Yang Chow" Fried Rice and is comprised with the same key-ingredients with Diced BBQ Pork, Diced Chicken, Shrimp and Scrambled Eggs with rice. 
Fried Rice: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Z_y97di6ovwsjFjCBRoMZg?select=lUVLzMKbPbgrDAGbaTpVtA

The $6.00 Chicken wings had 10 assorted pieces battered to a nice crisp with a touch of Asian spice. The two combine with complimentary "Hot" tea teamed well to satisfy our hunger.
Chicken wings: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Z_y97di6ovwsjFjCBRoMZg?select=F6xy_7JxpfnP36xlPA2ogQ

Our friendly waitress, Serena, did a wonderful job by being helpful and assisted our need(s) when needed. 
Serena: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Z_y97di6ovwsjFjCBRoMZg?select=ZDvckrVhOhjxb9DVk1jmig

My Mastercard was accepted for our lunch.

Who cares about the name of the restaurant. With good food and friendly service, this restaurant (with the red Yelp-sticker) is a better alternative than my usual, "Burrito!"

"I can't believe I just said that!"
author: Matt G.

description: This place is boss... great family ran restaurant with great service. I highly recommend this place
author: Derick R.

description: If you're a vegetarian looking to munch, get the veggie chow mein! Various vegetables are incorporated into this pleasant dish, and you'll have leftovers for an awesome lunch.
author: Ashley F.

description:
A big fan of this place. I live down the block and eat here more than i should :D Standard Chinese-American takeout fare. Nice portions and friendly service.

Some of my go-to dishes include:
Spicy basil eggplant with tofu
Mongolian beef
Honey walnut prawns
Almond chicken chow mein
Pho Ga 
Avocado egg rolls
Crab rangoon
author: Gianni M.

description:
Flavorful food, albeit a little salty. 

Extra bonus: they play Taylor swift and backstreet boys
author: James J.

description: Probably the best Pho I've had in the Mission! Will be my local go to place when I am in need
author: Tyler L.

description:
Totally tasteless pho :( portion was huge but it was way too salty and I couldn't even get myself to take the leftover home.........  I would stick to the chinese stuff here. I should have trusted  Ermagerd such bad pho.

Redeemed one star for the awesome waitress and service doe.
author: Alexis P.

description: i love punjab. the service is great and the price is too. I love the avocado egg rolls and the pho. sometimes egg fu yung. yum!
author: Ryan F.

description:
Ordered the spicy basil chicken combo plate and an order of pot stickers to go. When I got home I found that my spicy basil chicken had somehow turned into tofu with eggplant. Oh well, can't be bothered to take it back. The food is pretty bland. The tastiest thing was the pot stickers. Sad but true. I kind of liked the atmosphere of the place though. I wouldn't mind trying their soups sometime...

2nd Attempt: Ordered pot stickers and honey walnut prawns, to go. Tasted okay I guess. Walnuts were burnt. Still have burnt taste in my mouth. This experience cemented my earlier rating of this place.
author: P U.

description: I recently tried this place with a friend that has been going here for years and loved it! The shrimp fried rice is THE BOMB! Very tasty and LOTS OF SHRIMP....Full size shrimps. Not the pee pee sizes you usually get from other places. The BEST thing about their fried rice: NO PEAS!!! Their soups are fantastic as well and they are very friendly.
author: This Is M E.

description:
This place is so unexpected!

I love Chinese food, but it's so hard to find a descent one that use good ingredients. So surprised to come across a Chinese restaurant (especially in the Mission) that delivers. The service is super friendly too, our water and tea are always topped off.

Decor is very lacking in the uttermost level. Not sure why anyone would think having a diner inside a chinese restaurant works (especially with neon signs).

All the awesome food we got:
- General tso chicken. They use white meat!
- Punjab fried rice. Huuuge portion
- Egg roll

Definitely will come back!
author: Novalina N.

description: Friendly family owned business. Great food, awesome waitress and great service. I love their Punjab Wonton Soup definately the best in SF!  Food is tasteful and afordable. Felicia is a star in the kitchen. A mission gem!
author: Valerie V.

description: I have come back for cheap lunch options and i am glad it exist. it's adequate for a Chinese fast food place...but it's AMERICANIZED CHINESE FOOD. we don't or almost NEVER dip all our meats in flour and then deep fry them before stir frying and then cover them with loads of chillies and salt and peppers...you ONLY do that to low quality meats to cover up its oldness and lack of cooking skills in properly flavoring meats. That's all...
author: Xiu L.

description:
My tummy is currently making noises that I didn't think a stomach could make. 

Dont go here. And if you must, do not get the punjab wonton soup.
author: Alana Z.

description:
Punjab is a great $ (one money/inexpensive) restaurant.  I've been a handful of times now, each time I'm able to find what I'm in the mood for.  Spicy, soups, chow fun, pizza, pho, broccoli and beef, seafood, green beans, etc.  

Lots of space.  The staff works hard and remembers it's customers, that's unusual.
author: Cherry F.

description: The restroom is dirty and there is no toilet seat covers! The so called chinese food is  a disaster! Too many flavors and confusing  taste bud.
author: Wilson S.

description:
Dive chinese-american food.  Delicious!  

We always get something with eggplant in it; for some reason, they get the perfect texture and flavoring on their eggplant, and it is divine.  

I didn't like the avocado rolls so much... strange flavor to deep fry and put into a roll.  

We'll definitely come again.  I like to see what other people are ordering, and order that same thing.  Mostly fried rice and noodle dishes.  Highly recommend the eggplant special, though!
author: Andy C.

description: This place was absolutely repulsive. The clientele were sketchy - and I'm euphemizing. The place is dirty. The menu is overpriced. The food is processed and salty. The cook lady is RUDE. We were offered a soup or salad for our meal - selected a salad - and then were told soup was our only option. My mom wanted to walk out. I insisted we stay b/c the place has 4-stars. IT SUCKS. I warned them I would be yelping this place low, and they just said - "please don't." DON'T GO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Andrew K.

description: I guess this place opened up in 1970 and the best way I can describe it is an old school American dinner that serves some pretty good food at more than reasonable prices. It's not a 4 star restaurant. It's a no frills, keeping it real, 4 star experience. Try the banh mi sandwiches!
author: Mike E.

description:
This place was opened up back in the days when it was still cool to wear leisure suits and "TV rental" was a thing. The spacious interior contains frozen moments from that time (like the giant rotary phone) and they imbue the place with a kind of mystery and longing - which is so hard to come by in this now-so-hip neighborhood, currently bent on mercilessly expelling from its nethers anything that stinks of gaudy design and "value" food not considered by urban leisure magazines to be the latest and the greatest in gastro-entertainment. This is one of the largest restaurant interiors you will ever visit in this city (there is also an upstairs private party buffet area), which is truly a wonder considering it's a privately-owned non-corporate establishment scrambling for survival in one of the priciest areas in town by serving straight-up, no-nonsense Chinese American midgrade.

Yes. This is American Chinese, with some straight-up "American" and a bit of Pho thrown into the mix. More rarified and decadent items like the Honey Walnut Prawn appetizer or the Punjab Spicy Eggplant Chef's Special hang out among standard-issue glazed chicken items, noodle and eggroll combos, and the heady aroma of wonton broth. No, it's not snob-approved, Michelin-rated, five star fare. No mixologists are on call to make sure you have the sexiest, hippest cocktail north of LA. If you were dumb enough to believe in the existence of bung, this is the kind of place you'd suspect of serving it to you. Whatever you are eating probably won't be free-range or organic. It might even have MSG. But it is good, yummy, and fairly cheap - and in a neighborhood where the $20 meal in some over-decorated ponce-hole is quickly becoming the standard, places like this need the locals to get behind it and support it with their economic votes. (As a matter of fact, they recently had to whore themselves out to some HBO TV series as - get this arrogance! - an unused restaurant space one of the handsome, privileged urbanite protags is possibly trying to turn into his awesome fusion tapas lounge or whatever. Que lamé.)

Favorite items at this place include the Hunan Fish (some of the other dishes in that seafood fold-in are quite good too, like the Ginger Fish - though the Hunan Shrimp is a bit lacking in texture, honestly), the aforementioned Spicy Eggplant Chef's Special, and the Avocado Egg Rolls. Apparently, their Pho is getting some rave reviews too.

If you're in the mood for this kind of thing, then you will leave very happy! My biggest regret is that it took me a year to actually eat there, (partly because it looks so gaudy and weird from the outside)...
author: Manfred D.

description: I had the best General Tso's chicken I've had since I moved to the bay area! The best part is... my son was eating pancakes! Great american breakfast food and amazing chinese food... all under one roof! The staff is very friendly and the food comes quickly! Large portions for small prices. I would definitely recommend this place, and will be coming back often!
author: Chase L.

description:
I've missed this place. Used to work in the neighborhood so would always stop by on a weekly basis. The place is weird--it's got an indian/pakistani name, looks like a diner and serves up everything from hamburgers to kung pao chicken. i love it. best bet are the lunch plates--soup, rice and entree for about $6. my favorite is the spicy eggplant. mmm..not the most authentic chinese place, but it does the job.

The ladies behind the counter are super sweet and really make you feel at home. Hope to be back in the area again soon so I can stop by.
author: Joe C.

description: This has become my occasional lunch spot. I started off only getting the wonton soup with prawns (which is really good) but their garlic chicken, pork buns, and fried rice are amongst other things on the menu that haven't disappointed me. I'll have to make more trips and discover other things on the menu. If you're in the area and want either American style or traditional Chinese food, stop by!
author: Jamie M.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. Been coming here for 6 years. Great flavor, great service and tons of options!
author: Melissa M.

description: Great food!! Delicious and great service. I think this is one of the best chinese restaurants I have visited in a while. Serene is also great and a people person. She goes out of her way for her costumers.
author: Lorena D.

description:
An Indian-named restaurant run by old Chinese ladies with parts of the menu named after unknown celebrities like "Felicia"?  Of course I had to try Punjab's country-fried steak!

The country-fried steak was thin and the breading consistent and crispy.  The gravy somehow tasted clean and healthy, while still being rich and thick in flavor.  The side of string beans was snappy, revealing that they did not come from the freezer, and the complimentary soup enhanced my appetite.  The portions were fair for the price, and easily overwhelmed me into a post-lunch food coma.
author: Andrew M.

description: One of the most underrated restaurants in the city. It's pretty weird though. Starting with the misleading name (note this is not an Indian restaurant). There are often some funny characters inside. The menu has everything under the sun including Chinese food and American food. BUT, it's all really good. They're breakfasts used to be amazing but they don't serve that meal anymore.
author: Alex A.

description:
Live in the mission and craving good chinese food? This is your spot.

Those avocado spring rolls sound so bomb right now!

I can vouch for the combo-won ton soup, beef chow fun and Felicia's famous eggplant! 

Not to mention, their wine's; although limited, are pretty solid.
author: Joel L.

description:
Big place, good for un-nitpicky parties, standard Americanized Chinese food and a pho menu. 

Tip: If you order pho for lunch and the waitress asks if you want the combo, it's not a lunch combo! She means the pho with the tripe, tendons, and meatballs. 

I made this mistake. I ordered pho tai and I meant it. I said yes to "combo" thinking I was getting a spring roll or a salad in the deal but no. It ended up not being a tragedy because the bowl was so friggin' huge that I had my fill while still avoiding everything I didn't want. Seriously - there must have been an entire package of rice noodles in that bowl. It was endless! And not bad. Salty and full of tripe, sure, but easily the best pho I've had in a Chinese restaurant named after an Indian state.

Two other people in my party of 5 had to go with second choice items because what they ordered was no longer available (see what I mean about good for un-nitpicky people?). Everything that showed up was huge portions and good if not great.
author: Will R.

description: Typical American-Chinese food... but bless them for being open regular hours on Thanksgiving! I LOVE YOU GUYS!!!
author: Denise B.

description:
The decor here is really really ugly. It's mermaid green tiles with a random empty aquarium. It's a huge restaurant with a counter off to the side. Makes you think twice about eating here. 

This place is too Americanized for my taste. I took my dad here since it was close by and he was extremely disappointed. Their menu was entirely in English. They served a lot of Americanized Chinese dishes and of course American dishes. They even serve pizza. I saw crab rangoon pizza, BBQ chicken and other crafty creations. As tempting as it sounds, I decided to just order the House wonton soup, for about $7. When I got my food, it was full to the top. There were 12 decent sized dumplings, yep I counted! The meat toppings included chicken, pork, and shrimp. Not a bad dish but the soup eventually tasted really salty. My dad didn't like his (we ordered the same thing) and couldn't even finish half of it.
author: Connie C.

description: They serve regular diner brunch, and excellent chinese food, and both cuisines are delicious!  It also sports an interesting atmosphere, in case you are looking for an entertaining Sunday morning.  Also, if you get a brunch item, you get a complimentary mimosa or sparkling beverage (any additional ones are $2 each).  You can also buy a dozen fortune cookies for $1.  I will definitely go back!
author: Ling W.

description:
I recently had the opportunity of visiting SF General Hospital and decided to try this place after my visit, I'd actually just got my medical marijuana card, which, excitingly enough, makes me, a Texan who's lived here nearly a year, feel like I've finally gained my San Franciscan status.  But whatever, on to my initial experience at Punjab.

As I walked up the corner of 24th and Bryant, I noticed this restaurant and thought, hmmm, Indian food in the Mission, sounds nice, maybe I'll try this.

As I walked in, I didn't smell the typical curry smell of an Indian food place, in fact, just a clean odor of Fabuloso, which made me think of Mexico, and then noticed the strange Chinese decor everywhere, and a fish-tank without fish inside.  There was a 50's diner feel to the place as well, which, again, threw me, as the restaurant had an Indian name, Chinese dragons and crap all over the walls, and looked like a greasy spoon, but certainly didn't smell like one.  Only in San Francisco, I though to myself.  The whole layout focuses on a kind of darkish-greenish color, like forest green or something.

So I sat down at the bar/diner area facing the kitchen in a quite comfortable green swivel-chair, at the greenish-colored bar and was greeted by a Chinese/Malaysian lady of indeterminate age, whom I later learned was named Serene, or Serena, something like that. I tried the Punjab soup upon Serene's recommendation. Spicy but not overly so, shrimp won-tons that weren't overly dry or gushy, chunks of kohlrabi or baby bok-choy, in a large bowl, piping hot and utterly delectable.  They had Tsing-Tao beer, and other selections, all very reasonable.  

As I ate my soup, I recognized that there were a number of American offerings on the menu, so I quizzed the chef and Serene as to the quality of the American food they served there, and they both assured me that it was very good.

So, I took the 19-Mission from the TL all the way back to this restaurant on Sunday, soon after I'd tried it for the first time, with my girlfriend, for a little adventure, and we had brunch here.

I can't say enough good things about the brunch as well, I order Chicken Fried Steak with eggs over-easy and hash-browns, which also came with two sourdough pancakes, I think the full cost of this giant order was around 11.00 or less.  Unbelievable price, and with a free mimosa as well!  My girlfriend had some huge omellette, which came with some other sides, and again, a free mimosa, for around 8 or 9 dollars, again, out of this world prices.  For only 2 dollars more you could get another mimosa, so we began killing mimosa after mimosa, all the while being attended very attentively by Serene, who's friendly demeanor topped off the experience making it as perfect as it could get.  

Unfortunately it was super-hot that day, we'd intended on doing some shopping in the Mission, but were both too full to shop, so bussed back to the Tender-Nob and enjoyed some of the meds I'd found at the dispensary recently.  We both slapped ourselves silly for not ordering some of that delicious Punjab soup to go, as it would've suited our munchies perfectly.

All in all, I can't say anything bad about this place, despite the quirky Chinese decor, way too much green color on everything, the somewhat confusion selection of food, and finally, the name, Punjab, which just throws you completely off, but hell, they could call it 'Jack-Face' 'and I'd still eat here. This place is a true gem, and the patrons that I met whilst in my drunken mimosa reverie all seemed to love it as well, one sweet elder lady named Vera has been coming to this place for like 40 or 50 years.  And that shows me that this place has been dedicated to turning out good food and pleasing customers for a very long time.  You just don't find that these days.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
After growing up with Chinese food, you end up knowing which places are good or bad. You also become wary of trying new restaurants out fearing the possibility of eating bad Chinese food. Because of that...I ordered the breakfast here! 

I ordered the (I forget the name) spinach mushroom omelet.   Their omelets are a great deal because they come with your choice of potatoes and pancakes or toast.  Their breakfasts before 2pm come with a free mimosa, too.  

The decor was elegant; fancy when it needed to be and looked like they maintained the restaurant well.  I couldn't really see much because my friend's and were eating when they had a blackout. The cook had to prepare food with a mining hat on, the ones with a flashlight on a hard hat. 

The omelet had tons of spinach in it and the pancakes were the best I've had in a very long time.  They were so soft and fluffy. I think I'll here instead of IHOP, but IHOP is all day breakfast though.  The mimosa was alright. I wasn't in the mood for a drink, but the concept is great.  

I had a bite of their fried rice. It was pretty good. One day, maybe not next time, I'll try their Chinese cuisine.  Til then, I'm gonna have those yummy pancakes again.
author: Lisa X.

description:
Is there anything more random than a Chinese restaurant called Punjab?  Well, yes, of course there is, but that's pretty random.

4 stars for the people - they simply couldn't be nicer or more engaging.  The food is mostly decent to good - potstickers are tasty and I appreciate that they aren't a molded lump of meat that falls out of the wrapper - you can actually take two bites and get both pork & wrapper - yay!  Apparently they are made in-house by Mama, who is the cutest lady you'll ever see.  Kung Pao Chicken, Broccoli Beef and the other Chinese standards are good.  Won Ton Soup is to DIE for, especially in the winter when you've got a little bit of a cold.

They get a lot of regulars, which is encouraging. I'm doing my best to support Punjab, the Chinese restaurant with the Indian name in burrito alley. Random.
author: Julie L.

description:
This odd little gem has recently become a go-to dinner spot for my group of friends. 

We wandered in off the street one day, somewhat baffled by the odd naming, stranger decor, and complete lack of customers in this giant space. We thought it might be a front of sorts. But with inventive items like crab rangoon pizza and korean beef tacos, it seems to be trying too hard to be a front.

anyway, the service is always great and the prices are like, stupid cheap. For two of us we can usually do an appetizer, two dishes, rice and two beers for 25 bucks. (pbrs are 1.50!)

We usually split a slice of the crab rangoon pizza. It's odd but quite good, tastes exactly like something (eggs benedict mixed with mac n cheese??!) but so far I haven't figured out what (not quite crab rangoon). The kung pao prawns (or anything) are bomb, szechuan chicken's ok.

This place is by no means the best chinese place I've ever been to. Yeah, it's a little on the greasy side, I dunno about some of the ingredients, etc. But hey, what's life without a little adventure? Plus when pleasantly day drunk, few things hit the spot quite like some greasy spoon style chinese fare.
author: Kay M.

description:
A Chinese restaurant called Punjab! Lol... There was nothing wrong with this place. Good food and friendly service. Nice little neighborhood joint. I will return again... 

My sister and and a friend sat down for dinner last night we order avocado eggrolls, wonton soup, peking ribs and egg plant cooked with tofu.


Avocado egg rolls were bomb, soup was nice after a long bike ride in the cold wind. Peking ribs were good they have bones in them and the egg plant dish was awesome....they cooked the eggplant to wear the skin was just lightly crispy it was very nice!
author: Clara H.

description:
The Mission and its environs are not exactly known for authentic Chinese food.  On the plus side, it is known for, you know, Chinese restaurants with an Indian names, serving American diner food mixed with American Chinese food, served by hunchbacked old Chinese ladies who could be found at any such established in a semi rural Chinese town.  Yay.

On my trip there, M and I ordered the salt and pepper pork-chop, my standard go to at Chinese places, mixed stir friend greens, and something else that was generically American Chinese but that I can't remember.  The Pork Chops were decently tasty but a couple of orders too greasy.  The greens were varied in look but not as much in taste, probably owing to the sauce/oil they were prepared in.  Now that I think about it, the third dish was probably sweet and sour chicken, which I think I was left unimpressed by.  

Still, the portions were more than generous, the prices cheap, the parking ample, and the service pleasant.  As such, if you want unassuming Chinese food in the mission/portero area, Punjab might not be a bad idea.  Just don't expect anything exceptional.

3 Sweet and Sour Stars
author: Leon K.

description:
Had the General Tso's chicken last night and it wasn't very good - a little on the salty side.  And the place felt like walking into a time warp.  It was deserted at 9pm on a Friday, and was in a huge space that couldn't ever possibly be filled, which gave it a weird eerily quiet and tacky vibe.  

Pot stickers were decent though.  But I won't be coming back...
author: Clayton S.

description:
A favorite spot for Chinese chow in SF!

Good food, good prices, and friendly service!

If you're somewhere around La Mission, and have a hankering for some good Chinese Food, Punjab is the spot!
author: John N.

description:
I am Asian and normally hate Americanized Chinese food. I have regular cravings for this place.

It is cheap and the portions are generous (like most Chinese places). But most of all, the plates are filled with veggies and the food is not too oily. I actually DON'T walk away feel like my skin is oozing oil after dinner at this place. And yet it's still so TASTY like Chinese food is. 

The most important thing is that these people know how to cook. Whether the taste of their dishes happen to suit your personal preference or not, you can't argue with the fact that their chicken and shrimp are always amazingly tender, their veggies are perfectly steamed, and their fried items and ridiculously crispy. Some of the fanciest restaurants I've been to can't even get that right. And at that point, no amount of saffron or pretty plating makes a difference.

This is not a high-end place. less than 20% of customers here are under 100 on any given night (or maybe just the times I choose to go). But the food is tasty, the service is great (very atypical of Chinese places, I know), and the price tag is astonishingly low. Definitely a place to hit up if you're craving some take-out chilling on the couch. Definitely NOT a place to take your date.

Brunch serves free mimosas and are dirt cheap. I've had the brunch there many times and I am always surprised at how much food there is and how low the bill is. As for the American food on their menu, you can find better places in the Mission for a few dollars more. 
But their Chinese food is the bomb.

I recommend the walnut prawns.
author: Diane W.

description:
WHY do people like this place?  I am not a picky eater at all and I couldn't even stomach three bites.

Based on Yelp reviews, my husband and I tried Punjab for dinner last night.  Man, I don't know what you Yelpers are thinking!

We ordered the appetizer platter, the Szechuan Chicken, the Sesame Chicken and rice.  The items on the platter were deep fried to the point that the prawns were almost indistinguishable from the egg rolls.  As an after-thought, they brought sticky jars of sauce which were filthy.

Both chicken entrees seemed like scoops of the same thing --with just some sesame seeds thrown on the sesame chicken.  They were deep-fried globs of something that used to resemble poultry, drenched in corn syrup and red food dye.  Absolutely gross.

After one piece of each type of chicken and a couple bites of rice, I was ready to go home and cook dinner.  No doggie bag needed as I don't even think our pooch would eat this crap.

Look, I expected it to be an old school Chinese dive.  But this was inedible.  And for those Yelpers who think this stuff is "authentic Chinese," you're kidding yourself.  This class of food is called tourist Chinese food and sometimes, it's even pretty good.  However, the places that serve this stuff, usually have an entirely secret menu of real Chinese food for their Chinese patrons.

I'm giving two stars instead of one because it was basically clean, the service was prompt and the bill was cheap; $25 for two, including wine.
author: Amy A.

description: This place has amazing dishes. My favorites are the mongolian beef and sweet and sour pork.  The soups are good too. Dang good.
author: Pablo H.

description: Good (not great) food prepared quickly. Large portions. Very inexpensive. Ample seating.
author: Daniel C.

description:
This is not a five star chinese restaurant.  This is a five star review of the best 3-4 star chinese food deal in the Mission, hands-down.  

Punjab gets all kinds of things wrong:  Blah decor, semi-uncomfortable seating, understaffed tables, and unsettling oddities (empty fish tanks?) and a name that you'd expect would serve Indian cuisine instead.  At face value everything about it suggests mediocrity.

Then the food comes.  

Not only is it well above average but two people can enjoy 5 dishes here and the bill will be less than $25 guaranteed.  It makes no sense.  It's like the South Park episode where they go to the Mexican Space Program and get a ship for $200.  Is that the whole bill?  Si.

Pro tip:  Go for the family meals even if you're alone or with a couple, and substitute whatever for the Crab Rangoon.  It is to die for.  There's also a full (American-style) breakfast menu and free mimosas for brunch, which is random and awesome.

Just skip the unusual candy that comes with the bill or go straight for the fortune cookie, which may contain a future that reads like this:

"You will feel like you robbed this place when the bill comes"
author: niero g.

description:
I love Punjab for what it is - a cheap Chinese restaurant with quite a bit of character and an interesting history.  It's a great place for kids - particularly noisy babies and their inexperienced, neurotic parents. The waitress is very nice and personable. The menu includes some average diner fare (BLTs and the like) in addition to Chinese dishes, which is a nice change of pace (and sates the one hesitant, picky eater in the crowd).  They also serve breakfast with a free mimosa or glass of sparkling wine.  While hipsters are swarming St. Francis, you can have a decent, quiet breakfast without waiting in a 40 minute queue. 

The large dining space is quirky. The "regulars" are interesting to watch - like the elderly lady with the high-pitched voice who can sometimes be seen helping to fold napkins.

As far as the food is concerned, they always use fresh veggies which I can wholeheartedly appreciate.  Portions are huge, but prices are not. They  frequently offer "specials" (like vegetarian brown fried rice) and experimenting with difference appetizers (like avocado spring rolls) and such which keeps things interesting.
author: Who Knows N.

description:
I know why they are named Punjab, I once asked one of the ladies that has been working there a very long time, she said that the place was once Indian food back in the 70s, but the owner went back to India for and asked a Chinese guy to run the place while he was there. The Chinese guy added some Chinese food to menu while the other guy was gone, and eventually the Indian guy decided to never come back to San Francisco, so he let the Chinese keep the restaurant. That's how I remember the story, I asked her a long time ago. 

They are very nice their and work hard, especially Serene. 

Some of their best items:
- won ton soup
- walnut prawns
- beef broccoli

Their American food is excellent too, for example, they are open on Thanksgiving day and make an excellent American classic dinner.

You can ask for variations on menu items, they like to try out new things and often have special menu items.
author: Scott B.

description: I have no idea why there are so many bad reviews.  The veggies are not overcooked so they still have a crispiness to them (which is rare for American Chinese restaurants)  and what I really like is that they boil their chicken so it is really moist and its all white meat.  I usually get the spicy basil chicken with fried rice and an eggroll (combination) and I think it is great!  Crab Ragoon is also really good. The portions are huge for 7-8 dollars.  You can easily get 2-3 meals out of them. I am not really down for paying 20-30 dollars for some fusion food that people rave about but in the end lacks in flavor. It is not the healthiest food to eat but a great place to go when you don't feel like spending an arm and leg.  Also, I had the pho and I thought it was fantastic (can easily serve 2 people).  I went to 2 Vietnamese restaurants on Valencia and 18th and I think the pho here is better.  You can tell the broth has had more time to simmer than the other places I went where the broth was more watery and the meat not as tender.  It is a bit annoying when some yelp reviews below say this is not real chinese food,  yup you are right, it is americanized.... we get it.  We all understand that the menu has been americanized just like so many other ethnic cuisines.  There are some traditional items on the menu if people need to have "authentic" cuisine.  China is a big country with many variations in cuisine.  A large portion of Chinese immigrants came to America and created the Western version to fit American tastes, everyone knows this. The American Chinese food has been going strong for 20-30 years, it is common knowledge. Sorry, a bit of a rant there. Anyways, the staff is amazing and whenever I walk in the 90 year old grandma is sitting at a table cutting the snow peas and she is so cute.  They all work really hard considering how many to-go orders and patrons they have and only one waitress and 3 cooks. This is one of my favorite restaurants on 24th and because I like it so much this is my first yelp review! :-)
author: Jodie S.

description:
I love Punjab! Unlike a lot of trendy restaurants in the Mission, Punjab doesnt try to pretend its anything other than it is: good cheap Chinese food!

Plus the waitstaff are super friendly...even when they're slam packed busy.
author: Bigfrog W.

description:
Indian food name.
Chinese food.
American food.
Free mimosas or champagne when you come in for breakfast on the weekends, and then they are a dollar after the first glass.
Pretty good selection for food. 
mmmm food.
The wait time was a little slow given it wasn't crowded, but oh well.
I think I'll be coming back here.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I am tempted to give Punjab one star so that you won't go there. So that you wont bring all your hipster friends and ruin the whole thing. But I can't lie. I am in love...LOVE with Punjab. My boyfriend has even started singing songs about Punjab. We love it that much.

I've driven/walked past Punjab a million times and have just chalked it up to another dirty Chinese American restaurant that I would never eat in. Please feel free to maintain this illusion for yourself. 

My boyfriend works nearby and one day, his employee, sick of burritos, went into Punjab searching for more. My boyfriend ordered brown rice, salmon and asparagus and has not stopped going back ever since. At least three times a week, the friendly staff at Punjab fills his belly with delicious, nutriutious food. 

I stopped in to pick up an order for him one day and, unprepared, fell madly in love at first site. There were only four other people in the rather sizable dining room and some really mellow, classic jazz played at just the right volume. The sweet lady behind the counter (try to imagine a Chinese diner) prepared his order for me and even laughed at me when I was surprised that my bf had ordered an orange soda. 

I took the food to my bf's office and shared some of his chicken pot stickers. Holy Hell. Home-made from scratch, by hand...YUM. 

I decided we MUST try the breakfast. People, let me tell you something. For all of you hipster fools who stand in line for hours outside the Fountain or Boogaloos thinking you're gonna have the best breakfast ever and that its totally worth the wait...stay where you are. Do not approach Punjab. You will destroy it. 

I had the vegan sausage scramble (WHAT???) with FRESH spinach, mushrooms and jack. That vegan sausage was the best I've ever had. The hashbrowns were freaking perfection...crispy golden brown on the bottom, fluffy fresh potato, crispy golden brown top. The english muffins were just ok and the free mimosa was grossish. But it was free and half way through I didn't care. The food was amazing. 

The people who work at Punjab are kind, funny, friendly and warm. They're not super fast (we waited about 20 mins for food and there were only three other people there) but you don't care. You're being soothed by the jazzy tunes, your eyes are being mezmerized by the myriad of Chinese decor and the feeling that you're in on a great secret keeps you happy. 

The bill, for a vegan sausage scramble with toast and hashbrowns and a Jim's Big Five Omlette with double spinach, bacon, tomato and broccoli with home fries and toast AND two mimosas and a big pot of tea...was $20. Am I dreaming?

People, seriously. This is my new favorite restaurant. I keep trying to keep it to myself but I'm so thrilled at its existance that I just can't stop. 
I hope you ignore this review and ignore Punjab as well. Don't go there. Please.
author: Amber M.

description:
Punjab! I have a friend who swears this place is called Pungal. We think it's because he can't read cursive. 

Checked this place out late one night after being stood up by some hack who was supposed to show us his apartment. Eating here definitely kept our night from being completely jank. We walked in and couldn't figure out exactly where we were. Some sorta diner/dim sum-ish looking kinda joint. And that's exactly what it was. I heard you can get chicken fried steak with fried rice?? Ha! Tried the fried rice and some vegetable/tofu/eggplant deal that was loaded with garlic and basil. The best part about the fried rice was the peanuts. And basil and garlic in my mouth made me so happy. Plus it $1 beer happy hour (at like 9pm). Everything was pretty much good news. And our server was pretty nice. 

Pretty promising fasho.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I don't get why people would wait in line for St. Francis. But if it keeps this place easy to get into, that's fine with me.

FREE MIMOSAS! 

FREE MIMOSAS!

That was pretty much enough to get me to go here. But on top of that, it's just really good, standard American brunch food. Oh, and they have $1 fortune cookie bags.
author: Mark A.

description: I have to say, this place is kind of overrated. Everything about it is just blah; average. Nothing more to say than that: if you want average chinese food for an average price in an average restaurant (average by American-Chinese restaurant standards), go here.
author: Sean C.

description:
The most curious name I've ever seen for a Chinese restaurant, but we popped in anyway for a quick Saturday evening bite since my friend is not a fan of Mexican food.

So why 4 stars? Hard to explain, actually. But somehow this place just gave us some very good vibes in a rough neighborhood. It was decent and clean, and we didn't have to worry about having to go out the door horizontally after eating. Our server Serene was very warm and friendly. That's hard to find in any Chinese restaurant, let alone the Mission district. Serene made us feel that she cared about the food she served us. And that means a big deal on my list.

The food was average. Nothing out of this world. And the price was decent. Service was a bit on the slow side. But on the other hand, we took a long time to finish our meal, and we were never pushed to leave early. 

I'll definitely come back to this place again if I need a convenient, stress-free meal.
author: Yusaku G.

description: Vegetable chow fun is as fun as it sounds! The meal could easily feed 2, unless you are a champion, then my advise is to loosen your pants and go for the gold. Service is not so great, but the food makes up for it. Happy Chow FUN-ning!
author: Maghan K.

description:
I try not to throw the word "love" around much unless I really mean it.

I LOVE this place's eggplant veggie dish.

A little sweet. A little spicy. All eggplant. YUMMMMMMMY!

Super friendly service (sweet, helpful, modest people), beautiful interior with plenty of room, GREAT menu prices....

Need I go on?

I'm not kidding when I put 5 stars, people.

Check it out.
author: Kai S.

description:
Punjab, the fiance, and I have become more and more of a love triangle of late. It is so close to our house. It is so reliable. The people are so friendly. And the food is cheap and GOOD.

The quality of their food has gotten much better over the last six months. I'm not really sure what changed, but I haven't gotten a single thing I didn't love, and they used to be more hit-or-miss.

Last month I had a bad cold and was eating nothing but their wonton soup the whole time. Their orange chicken has lots of yummy pieces of orange zest all through it. The same waitress is always there and she can always recommend things to you, too.

And the time before last that we went there, the fiance finally took the plunge and ordered American food here. He got a hot dog. It wasn't even on the menu. They charged us, like, $2.50 for it. And he said it was really, really good.
author: Lynae Z.

description:
OLD SKOOL!!!

This is the kind of chinese restaurant that I started eating at in the late 80's. The food is made with love and served up by super friendly servers in a cool, retro chinese dinner like environment. I ordered sesame chicken as a combo, so the server gave me fried rice and one pot sticker on the side for $8.75. The sesame chicken was just what I was hoping for, large chunks of white meat, fried and then sauteed in a sweet and spicy sauce. My friend ordered sweet and sour chicken (I thought to my self 'oh, how original...blah') but I was pleasantly surprised that the sweet and sour chicken was the best I had ever had. I wasn't overly sweet and saucy like most other restaurant make. It was actually better than my sesame chicken.

An interesting thing about this place is that they serve up a full menu of home cooked American food like pot roast, steaks, and hamburgers. So, you can take several friends out to eat and everyone will find something tasty!

Oh, and this place is cheap, cheap, cheap! It's great for budget peeps and people that want to eat on the cheap!
author: Rex D.

description:
An interesting name for a Chinese place, and an even more interesting candidate for a five star sweep.

They caught my attention a few weeks back as I was headed home from another food adventure. The sign outside touted pancakes with fruit on top, one of my favorite brunch options, and I made a mental note to return soon.

This particular morning I was arising after a few hours spent dancing to the techy yet uplifting Jayech and was very hungry. And I was due at a wedding in a few hours so I couldn't go far. This was my chance to go back.

One of the lingering memories is the service. Exceptionally friendly and accommodating. I wasn't charged for egg whites in my omelet, and when I said I was going to take something to go and asked that items could be steamed, the waitress said almost anything. That's the opposite of what I usually get. The only thing she didn't accommodate was when I asked for plain orange juice instead of the free mimosa. Not sure why, but it was a minor misstep during otherwise stellar service.

For the food, my veggie omelet was huge, with one of the most impressive quantities and balance of eggs and veggies ever. Even better was the side options include bread or wheat pancakes, the latter being a rarity, especially as a free side. And for takeout, there was enough veggies and tofu to make two meals.

The fortune cookie with the check with a nice touch.

Service and food dramatically exceeded expectations. I'm glad I made it back, and I hope others give them a chance.
author: Jason B.

description:
Where's the beef?  I would say that is an appropriate title for this restaurant.  We ordered tomato beef and mongolian beef and both were actually really good, but the beef ratio to the amount of food we got was poor.  If not for that, I would have given this more stars.

Also, I was disappointed at the end of the meal to find there were NO fortune cookies in the bag!  How can a chinese restaurant not serve fortune cookies?  I'm just sayin...
author: Mac K.

description: I don't know what other people had, but this place is terrible. Nice service, but the food made me feel ill.
author: Zachary S.

description:
Disclaimer:  I am a Chinese food snob.

That being said, this place was ok.  Don't expect anything authentic, but if you want your run of the mill chow mein, fried rice, wontons, etc., it's not too bad.  I ordered the hot & sour soup, and it did the trick just fine.

I've never gotten any of their American cuisine so I can't comment on that.

Overall though, the prices are decent, and you can get a good meal for under $10.  The reason why I rated this relatively low was the service.  This is the 2nd time I was here.  I remember it being pretty good the first time I was here about 3 months ago, but when I went a few days ago, the lady was not friendly.  It wasn't like I came rushing in at 8:55 when they close at 9.  

Com'on now...you're in a customer service job.  Even though I was just getting take out, at least smile or pretend that you want repeat business...  It's not like I'm asking for a unicorn.
author: Alice C.

description:
there are a lot of very strange things about punjab.  very strange indeed.  like, why are you a chinese restaurant with an indian name?  and if you really are in fact a chinese restaurant, why do you serve grilled cheese?

hell if i know.

what i do know is that this restaurant is spitting distance from my apartment so when i'm hella jonesin' for some lo mein or chicken and broccoli, punjab is where i go.

is it the best?  gosh no.  it's just convenient and well... it's just... "not bad."  the food is okay, the decor is awful, but the folks who run this place are super sweet.

one thing i really want to know... if you've tried to crab rangoon pizza, please tell me what the feck it is.  i've seen it on the menu but do not want to order it but i'm so curious.
author: Lauren P.

description: I been coming here since i was a kid. I took my wife here when we started dating and she  loved it. Not the fanciest of chinese cuisine but the flavor is awesome. We kinda like everything on the menu...haha.
author: Jason S.

description: Wasn't expecting too much in this mission neighborhood. I saw this place all the time, very close to where I work. I bring my own lunch every day, except yesterday. I left the house in a hurry, so I decided to give this place a try. I ordered the simple egg plant with rice. Oh my! It was the best egg plant with garlic sauce I've ever had! The garlic sauce is so delicious! I will get my lunch here more often from now on!
author: The Black Cat C.

description:
Food is pretty bad. If you like dives because they're hipster-cool, then go for it. 
It's a sweet, family-run business, and I wish the food were better.
author: Bill S.

description: LOVED their breakfasts!  I had the eggs Benedict ...out of this world & the complimentary glass of Mimosa was an extra treat!  And the service was exceptional.  Met the owner Felicia..  great hospitality.   IF your in the mission area - I recommend stopping by.
author: ALICIA F.

description: I love this place!. Not greasy as others, and between garlic, ginger and secret spices there's no need for MSG. There potstickers are the best. The best way to test out their menu is at lunch time, with their reasonably priced lunch specials. My family has been eating here for three generations.
author: Ari A.

description:
My gf and I were just walking around 24th deciding what to eat for lunch.   And we walked by this place.   I saw the sign that said "breakfast till 3pm free mimosa".  So I went in.

We found it interesting that a Chinese restaurant serves American diner style breakfast and dinner as well.

I got one of the breakfast combo with chocolate chip pancakes.  It was really good, especially the pancakes.  It actually went really well along with the Chinese tea they had.   The mimosa was okay, but it was free, so no complain there.

The services was pretty good, she was really attentive and tried to have small talks with us.  I am Chinese so I talked to her a bit in Cantonese which probably amused her a little.

My gf got some eggplant/basil/beef stirred over rice, and she was completely blown away.

I can't say this place completely whoa me but I'd definitely come back and try something else.
author: Anthonio C.

description:
I finally figured out what they *don't* have on their menu!!!

ONION RINGS!!!

BOOOO....
author: Megan G.

description: I had the Ginger Beef with Scallions. It was exactly what I expected and had a good portion size.
author: Paul L.

description:
This place opened up back in '89 when I was a small kid living on Hampshire St. and 23rd St. Our family ate there a couple of times, but we never really went back to eat there after we moved closer to Mission St. I finally revisited it yesterday. It was my mom's b-day, she was feeling nostalgic, and I was (still am?) kinda broke, so it was a good choice for us.

The first thing that stuck out to me was the level of cleanliness. It can be less-than-stellar (and usually is) at many Chinese food restaurants in the Mission.
