One of the servers there, Judy, has been there since forever: she's just as kind as ever and is especially attentive. That's the next thing I like about the place, it's the inviting atmosphere.

But I guess the most important part is the food. I've had some really good and really crap Chinese food. The food here is definitely on the better end. They've tossed in many American dishes into their menu. We started off with complimentary tofu-seaweed soup that tasted pretty much like any other tofu-seaweed soup I've had before: nothing special, but it was still tasty.

For the appetizer, we ordered some avocado rolls on Judy's suggestion. Basically, it's an eggroll-like creation. It's fried wonton stuffed with avocado and other tasty things and it comes with a small saucer of sweet prawn-honey sauce which totally rocked. The combination of sweet-savoury, and the textures of crispy wonton and creamy avocado worked really well. 

For my main dish, I ordered the grilled sole, which comes with your choice of fries or mashed potatoes on the side. As I'm not the biggest fan of either, I asked for mixed vegetables in place of it and it was done with no problem. The vegetables were basic steamed vegetables (carrots, snow peas, celery, bok choy, broccoli), but with a twist: fresh chopped basil tossed in at the end. It lent to the vegetables this wonderful aroma, and gave them a slightly peppery-sweet flavor. It was a really good addition. The grilled sole was moist and flaked nicely and the portions were generous: there was totally enough for at least 2 people. It was a tad greasy, but overall it was super tasty and cheap!

My mom ordered a spicy eggplant-chicken dish. I found the eggplant a little overdone for my tastes. I like my eggplant to have some body  to it: this eggplant was one step before being mush. There were strips of roasted red bell peppers in it that I absolutely loved. This is a spicy dish, so have something to drink close by. Fortunately, we had a nice bottle of chardonnay to accompany our courses. This dish does come with a nice heaping of white rice which takes some of the edge off the spiciness. The bits of chicken in the dish are glazed with a thickish savoury, spicy, slightly sweet sauce.

We wrapped it up by getting a slice of carrot cake for dessert. On my way to the restroom, Judy stopped me. She said that she would wait for me to return before bringing out dessert. Making my way back after, she had prepared the dessert with a candle on top, which I thought was really nice of her. We both trekked back to the table and as we approached, Judy began singing happy birthday, and of course I joined in. It was really cool when everyone else in the restaurant joined in and sang along, too! My mom was totally loving it, it moved her to tears!  The carrot cake wasn't anything exceptional, but it was a nice way to top off the meal.

Talk about great service, good food and a really enjoyable dining experience. We ended up staying there for over 3 hours. I've never found a restaurant before where I've gotten so comfortable that I've lost track of time: that's a true testament to how inviting the atmosphere really is. I've decided: this is my new place for Chinese food, dining in or taking out, even if it's somewhat out of the way, I can definitely justify the longer trip. The bill was a very fair amount for the amount of food we had.

Oh, and they serve breakfast there, too. Pancakes, eggs, among other things, and on the weekends you get a complimentary glass of mimosa or sparkling wine with your breakfast. How much does that rock?!
author: Christopher R.

description:
This place was absolutely charming! The waitress was super nice and was on top of everything, making sure that we had everything we needed.  Cute diner atmosphere which I dig.  They had coco chip pancakes which I never seem to find and cheap and yummy Chinese food. 
Lots of options and excellent service. So glad we stumbled across this place!
author: Erica R.

description:
I live in the mission and LOVE burritos (shout out to La Corneta!) but sometimes when I get off BART at 24th and start the trek to my house,  I crave VEGETABLES which are hard to come by in taquerias.  So, tonight, when I really wanted some broccoli I decided to try "Punjab Chinese and American food."  I went in, ordered Szechuan (sp?) broccoli (only $6!) and brought it home.  It was great and there was enough leftover for my lunch tomorrow!   $6 for two broccoli meals!  

Plus the server was very friendly.  "No problem!"  

and, added bonus, the crowd in the place was very esoteric.  it kept me entertained while I waited for my broccoli.
author: Tara R.

description:
Disclaimer: I ate at Punjab after a full week's worth of grandma's homemade cantonese cooking. Beware.

For the last three years, Punjab has been a bit of a laughing matter in the household. Why? Well, it's called Punjab. Punjab Chinese American Restaurant. In the Mission. It's one of those places that you pass on your way to St. Francis Fountain and someone says, "Hey guys, how bout we go to Punjab instead?" And the crew keeps walking...

It must have been a full moon that fateful night because Punjab suddenly seemed like a great idea! We rounded up the roommies and headed out to the corner of 24th and Bryant. From the looks, smell, and feel of the place, it seemed legit. After surveying the reviews, we ordered:

Potstickers
Crab Rangoons
Wonton Soup
Beef and Broccoli
Punjab Chow Fun

Despite the low expectations and positive 4-star rating, I was disappointed (see disclaimer above). The rangoons were decent but the pork inside the potstickers and wonton was way too salty. The beef was over-salted as well. The chow fun was passable. I must comment  though that the service was fantastic. Our waitress was such a sweetheart!
author: Susan L.

description:
Since I just moved into a new neighborhood, I have a backlog of reviews to write.   Unfortunately, I've been slacking and my dreams of becoming a Yelp Elite are probably already in vain.  Sigh.  I didn't want to be in your snobby club anyway!  What was I supposed to be talking about?  Oh yeah, PUNJAB. 

Ok, so my new roommate suggested this place and since it's right around the corner I thought I'd give it a go for a quick dinner.  I had been eyeballing the Spicy Basil Tofu on the menu he brought home so I already knew what I wanted.   Walking in, the first thing I noticed was....holy crap, this place is  huge!  In a neighborhood of cramped taquerias and limited personal space, this place is strangely large.   

The only patrons were a large group of old folks chattin it up and having a good time.  It seemed obvious that this was their regular Friday evening deal.  I overheard them talking about the good ol' days and also how Phil (who is apparently 90) had four women up in his room the other night.  What a pimp!   Anyway, my point is, any place that attracts regulars with character earns stars from me.   One of the ladies informed me that Felicia makes great Spaghetti and meatballs on Friday nights.   Weird...but good to know. 

The staff was very friendly and were having a good time chattin it up with the patrons.  My food came out in under 10 minutes which always makes me happy when doing take out.  

My Basil Tofu was quite good.   Not exactly "spicy", but very flavorful and definitely hit the spot.   This is a great little alternative spot down here in burrito-land.   Good, cheap chinese food with friendly staff and a funky atmosphere.   I'll definitely be going back to see what else they have to offer....though I'll probably not go with the Spaghetti...that just seems wrong.
author: Scott W.

description:
100% THE BEST Wonton Soup in SF!  Trust me we have been coming here for years!  NEVER will you come here and NOT see the gals making FRESH wonton and potstickers, they do this between servings.

Go there and order their Punjab Wonton Soup it is loaded with wonton, shrimp, pork, chicken and greens.  The BEST broth ever, and their potstickers really rock too!

I also love any eggplant dish they make, their special fried rice and their fish specials.  Who cares about the friggen decor? I want some good grub!!

Felicia is a gem an she welcomes you like family, LOVE her smile too!

They use to have a parking lot, its an apartment building now...so take your time on the parking.
author: Bahvee V.

description:
Mediocre at best in terms of food taste. Yet it is cheap, fast and clean. The vibe is good...It is like visiting a Chinese-American grandma's house. The hot dogs and burgers are on the menu near the basil tofu and chow mein.  

It is rare in San Francisco to find a restaurant that seem to exude historical relevance and a place were you can find people over the age of 60 years old dining near you. It makes me respect Punjab on levels beyond taste.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Maybe it's not the best Chinese but it is good and the service is awesome.  One time I came in and ordered Beef and Broccoli and it was ready it literally two minutes!

And of course get the Crab Rangons you can never go wrong with deep fried cheese and crab!
author: Jason S.

description:
I absolutely love Punjab's. 

Okay, so it's not super fancy or organicky chinese. I like to think of the food as top-of-the-line hongkong style. Not super greasy, but the oils are there in quantities enough to make it tasty and savory. it's got the best soups EVER, yummy, and they are totally flexible on specially making whatever you want to order.

My fave dish are the avocado egg rolls they make, yum! They have really good orange chicken, too, and i love all their soups. They also have American fare, which is great for me because my kid hates Asian food but i live it, so it's a place we can both agree on when we want to go out to eat.

Punjab's is frequented by older, working-class people and families who live in the area (very kid friendly). It's almost got a diner feel to it, but i don't know many diners that offer free mimosas with sunday brunch! The restaurant has been there for years, everybody is super friendly, and the prices are sane. 

Support Punjab's!
author: XTA s.

description: Reminds me of the kinds of places I used to go to in college in Philly. Like an old diner, service very friendly, feels like a reliable neighborhood place to go when you're too tired to cook and you don't want to dress up. Efficient but not pushy. Chow fun seafood was ok, a little bland (maybe we got the white people's version?). Sesame chicken was disappointing, a little too crispy, not enough sesame for my taste. Egg flower soup was an unexpected bonus. Portions were large.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Yelp needs to add a "zero" star option for ratings.

I can try to be fair: my coworkers swear by their wonton soup. 

They also only go there when they're flat broke.

I made the mistake of going there once (actually, they had to drag me) and since I am super snobby about Chinese food (and Mexican)--especially hole in the wall joints, I tried to play it super safe and ordered some vegetarian chow mein. 

It was gross and greasy--and I got sick! I have never gone back. After a while, my coworker finally stopped asking me.

Sure it's cheap, but if you're in the neighborhood, just forego this place altogether and get yourself a burrito.
author: Dora A.

description:
I like this place. 

They play jazz music. The Food was good and the Waitress was accommodating to the changes I wanted to make to my grilled cheese sandwich. Its somewhat affordable and the place feels good.
author: H P.

description:
When you first hear the name you immediately think indian food. But then you find out its Chinese / American food. 

The won ton soup and pot stickers are excellent.  I also like the fish specials they have fairly often. Its a nice change of pace for me because I find myself always ordering Mongolian Beef or Beef with Black Bean Sauce over rice.  Which are also pretty good here. 

One of the cooks here used to work at this great place that used to be on like 22nd and third street called Isis. 

There aren't too many Chinese places I like to going to in the PH area. Eliza's is good but seems over priced for the quantity of food you get.
author: Lawrence S.

description: I know a lot if Chinese restaurants put MSG in their food, but when you can actually see the MSG crystals on your pork chop, that's just wrong...
author: Irwin T.

description: This is some solid, great-tasting Americanized Chinese food. Fresh ingredients, nice staff, rarely a wait, great prices - this is my go to for Chinese food now that Eliza's is closed.
author: Bradley H.

description:
I've worked at San Francisco General for twenty years now and I've eaten at Punjab, off and on, throughout that time.  Their menu is extensive - but what appeals most to me are the huge bowls of soup.  I always opt for the Punjab won ton soup, chock full of prawns, chicken and pork - a huge serving with about a dozen won ton in a savory broth with greens.  I always think I'll eat just half and save the rest for dinner.....but, somehow, I manage to consume every tasty morsel.  I can't resist their fried chicken wing appetizers, either - though I know they aren't high on the list of healthy eats.  Yummy, nonetheless and impossible to resist.

Felicia is lovely and, on days when I can't possibly get away for lunch, she's been known to bring it to me - bless her soul!
author: Carmen H.

description:
A funky place typical of the Mission.  Unlike a lot of places in this neighborhood, it has ample seating for larger groups, so a bunch of us went and the waitress was great about it.

The lunch specials are good on the weekend too so that's what we all ordered.  The outstanding dishes were lemon chicken, garlic eggplant and king kung pao.  The garlic chicken was just OK.  The rice, not-so-good but the portions were generous and I would go back.

We went there a week ago for the crab rangoon pizza and that was excellent.
author: Brenda B.

description: I have been going to this restaurant for 16 years, and I love it. They my order when I walk thru the door.  Now I have my husband hooked!  Thanks Felecia and Judy!  My favorite is the egg foo young and crab ragoons.
author: Prima M.

description:
Went here last Friday night for a friend's birthday dinner. I must admit that I was a bit skeptical about a Chinese food restaurant, located in the Mission, with an Indian name. I told my friend I was prepared to have my mind changed, but mostly a bit worried about what might arrive at the table.

My fears were unfounded.

Delicious items included: Crab Ragoon (super creamy!), avocado spring rolls, and Basil Eggplant.* The chow mein was standard (which is good!) and the wine list, although not teeming with selection, was cheap ($4/gls; $10-12/btl). Seven of us ate and had 1-2 drinks each for $100 before tip.

The only downside is that I had a bit of an upset stomach which started a couple hours after eating. Nothing crazy happened. It probably had to do with the amount of grease I consumed (my body's not quite used to it). It's also a safe bet that you'll get gassy after eating here. Just an observation from our group.

* My friend told me she's had the Basil Eggplant and its been undercooked (tough) in the past, although it was not that way last Friday.
author: Caitlin B.

description: Greasy spoon American-Chinese diner with a bottle of sriracha at every seat. Sat at the counter and was immediately served hot tea, asked for a vegetarian recommendation and within five minutes was chowing down a steaming plate of Spicy Basil Tofu (crispy) and brown rice. It was comfort food asian awesome. And cheap.
author: Danny T.

description: I would like to like a Chinese restaurant with an Indian name but I just don't. It's not good food and the service is not great either. Lots of people like it though, and maybe if you like fried food it's for you.
author: A R.

description: This restaurant is awesome for food and service. Who cares about the decor. What use is it to go to a restaurant with nice decor if the food and service sucks?! I have been eating at this restaurant for a few years and I must admit the food and service are what keep me coming back. I love that the menu offers a variety of food, why would you want the same old menu year after year? Kudos for having American and Chinese food! Having variety is a good thing. Keep up the good work Punjab and staff. Way to be unique!
author: I M.

description: I'm not a fan of Chinese food but this place has changed that. The workers there are very friendly. They have daily special even a dessert special which was delicious ( The Won ton Sundae). I usually get it to go and every time I order something different. I tried the Happy Chicken which is very good. It has reasonable prices and lots to choose from.
author: Lind G.

description: I thought everything we ate was delicious, my BF was so so with the food. The service a little slow but friendly. Very reasonable prices. We only had Chinese, so I can't speak for other items on the menu.  The atmosphere was not the best, but we sat in a table by the window where we were able to see this crack head women get in her car pick up some dude and smoke their pipe, VERY ENTERTAINING!! If ever back in San Fran in that area and want Chinese will be back, it was very tasty and fresh.
author: Ingrid C.

description: MMMMMMMM, lol....  I have been going to Punjab's literally for over 26 years!!  They are incredible...  good price, good food, good amount!!!  and friendly service!!
author: DEANNA W.

description:
I have been coming to this place before I hit puberty. This place is kind of a family tradition we come for on birthdays-don't ask me why. 

Everytime I come I look forward to seeing that clock they have on the wall open up on the hour every hour to see  a little song and dance. I know that has no correlation bewteen reviewing and food, but who cares!

Don't come here if you expecting the quickest of service or the best tasting food. Don't come here if you drive an expensive car-chances are it won't be there when you leave. Don't come here on your first date either. 

Come here if your looking for a cheap, chill place to eat. They have great prices, good food with a kicked back atmosphere. The portions are huge as well-enough for some chow mein for lunch at work the next day.
author: T.J. M.

description: don' t get confused by the shabby environment. The service is very sweet and the food is simple, but fresh and delicious.
author: Daib S.

description: great for cheap typical chinese food with HUGE portions! I went at around 4 on a thursday and the place was almost empty - which was nice.  They also have a small selection of pretty cheap wines which is nice. We had the $12 sauvignon blanc, which was not bad, especially for the price! We also ordered delicious crab rangoons and general tsaos chicken - also delicious.   Great service. I will probably go here again.  Oh! another nice tough is that every table gets a pot of fragrant jasmine tea - very nice.
author: Jo A.

description:
Punjab is the shit for so many reasons it's disgusting.

Let me name a few:

1)  It's CHEAP.  Like, go in, split an appetizer and two entrees with a friend and you each pay $10 cheap.  
2)  It's a Chinese/American restaurant that serves breakfast 
3)  If you go on Saturday or Sunday brunch you get a FREE (FREE) mimosa.  
4)  Their breakfasts come with a choice of toast or PANCAKES.  Which means you can get an omelet, potatoes and pancakes for $8.
5)  It's never busy.  You can stare out the windows at all the doobs waiting for an hour for brunch at St. Francis while you sip on your FREE mimosa and eat your breakfast that costs half the price.  
6)  They have what might be the best fried chicken i've had in the city.  Not kidding, people.  I think it's called Polynesian Fried Chicken, it's a house special, and i don't know what exactly qualifies it as Polynesian, I just know it was delicious (*note, I was a little drunk when eating this but often am when eating fried chicken so its a fair assessment).  

Honestly, i'd almost prefer that you all don't believe anything I wrote in this review so that you never ever come here cuz i'll be pissed if i start having to wait.  Yeah, so everything I said was a lie.
author: Tom T.

description: Stumbled across this place when the fam was looking for some Chinese on a Sunday night.  Good food and great service! Our waitress Serene was very patient and helpful as she navigated through my family's substitution-laced order and got it all right! Try the avocado egg rolls there off the hook!
author: Norm N.

description: I can't believe I lived above this restaurant for almost 2 years before setting foot inside.  The food is good, the price is right, the fortune cookies are insight-fully accurate.  The menu has plenty to choose from, making this spot pleasing for just about any appetite.  My regulars are vegetarian or seafood options, but I have a serious weakness for their fried appetizers.  We usually do take out (nice quick service), but sometimes sit downstairs at the counter for brunch (also nice quick service) which is super delicious, and a rockin' deal.  Who can say no to a free mimosa?  Not me!
author: Katrina M.

description:
Punjab is one of those great neighborhood places that you can always rely on for an awesome meal.  And that meal can be anything from szechuan chicken, basil prawns, and won ton soup to chicken fried steak and BLTs.  And look out for the occasional specialty pizza with exotic mushrooms that Felicia might whip up out of the blue.  I was skeptical at first at such a wide range of foods, but they nail each dish.  I went recently with my boyfriend and his family, some of us getting traditional chinese and others fish n' chips and steak, and we were all happy with our dishes.   The tofu is perfect, the rock cod nice & spicy with great presentation, and the spicy eggplant is my favorite.  If you don't want to share, their combination plates are perfect.  You will always leave with a box for leftovers, it's a great value.

But mostly, the people there are great.  Take the time to get to know the owner, wait staff and chefs...they are genuine, friendly and will give you great recommendations (good call on the Avocado Spring Rolls!), and they are the reason I am taking the time to write a review that I so rarely do.  There are lots of fancy restaurants springing up in the Mission that will come and go, but Punjab has been around for over 20 years for a reason!
author: sophie s.

description:
We were out seeking Thai, but found it closed to we ended up trying this place out, and turned out to be great!  Everyone really enjoyed their meals.  

I got a combo of fried prawns and shrimp fried rice.  The prawns (6 of them) were absolutely delicious! The shrimp didn't have much taste to them, but the rice was mmm mmm good.  $8.50 is pushing it for a meal of that size, but it did completely fill me up.  It's just nice to get left overs too, ya know?
author: Levi B.

description: Great place!!! Have been coming here since I was a kid and have since moved on from their Burgers and Fries (I Know) to the other great dishes... Cashew chicken over rice is bomb..and of course the staples , chow mein, fried rice, and egg roll plates are all really good...staff is really friendly and since I only live across the street eating there has never crossed my mid so I don't really know, but people always seem to be having a good time.. great place to try out!
author: Mig I.

description:
I've lived a block away from Punjab for 15  years, and I love this place. The staff are wonderful and courteous and they have a great selection of food.

Granted, not everything on the menu is outstanding. A lot of it is just average, (still good, though) but their potstickers can NOT be beat! I'm also a huge fan of their pork buns, and hey, their American food is pretty tasty, too! (Fish n chips especially.) Orange chicken is always a great bet, and for what it's worth, their burgers are nice. (way better than the overpriced crap at St. Francis) Especially since everything is served with a smile and a "Hi! How are you today?" If you are a regular, they know your name, even if you don't remember ever telling it to them.

I also love the atmosphere. I have an affection for "fixtures"..  i.e. people who are more than just regulars, they seem like they belong there and they simply came with the building. Punjab has that. No matter what time I go there for food, there will be that same group of folks at the front table, chatting. I hope they never leave. We need more places like this. Joints that serve great food, at reasonable prices (extremely reasonable), and are populated by fixtures.

You won't find a skinny, white, emo, hipster for miles. IT'S AWESOME.
author: Jonny P.

description:
It's local, it's cheap, it's your friendly fried Chinese joint in the neighborhood. I'm satisfied with orange chicken, sesame chicken, and everything else typically American to order from a Chinese restaurant. Overall? The perfect 3 star place.

PS - does anyone know why their place is freakin' huge?
author: Matthew G.

description: uh .. i cant reccomend this place.I shoul dhave taken it as a sign when we went and it was  empy  besides us , but at least we had great service . I went for the crab rangoons but was very disapointed. They were burned ...I also ordered the avacado rolls which i did not end up eating becuase they were brown . The won ton soup was just so so . A couple was standing watching us eat the whole time and when we left they tried to go grab our money we left on the table. I would advise to stay away ! My girlfriend said it was the worst meal we have ever had together :( ..I must admit it was a little weird to see them advertising candy bars .. they did have a interesting variety of things for a chinese restraunt but def wont be returning.
author: Ms. P.

description:
Satisfying and sweet and yummy.

There are some days when I get home after manhandling my bike off the BART and I'm just feeling too lazy to cook. Sure, I could make myself an egg sandwich, but what I really want is something delicious and crunchy and sweet and hot. Punjab has totally got me covered.

I've had some completely satisfying chicken-in-various-sauces, surprisingly interesting and tasty egg rolls, and the service, even for take-out, is friendly and willing to wait while I try to decide if I want sesame chicken or the one with the crazy name.

It is also not Mexican, which makes a nice change of pace when you live near 24th and you've already had tacos for brunch and a burrito for linner.
author: E.O. S.

description:
If you want a restaurant with a "local" atmosphere, this is it. From the people that are there everyday just to hang out to the employees working the restaurant, you get a very friendly atmosphere. Reminded me a bit of the sitcom, "Cheers" minus the bar setting and adding a chinese restaurant setting of course. :)

Try the Singapore style noodles or the Spicy Fried Chicken... yum!
author: A Y.

description: Treat yourself to the best kept secret in the city! Don't let the name fool you.... It's Chinese and American. (long story, don't ask.) Family secret.... They are testing creative pizza's.... I just finished my leftover Broccoli Beef, Sweet and Sour Pork and the Singapore noodles... I think I might have to go get more!!!
author: Kenneth C.

description: a little on the very greasy side but than again thats what chinese food is all about , mangolian beef is amazing as well as the avocado rolls, veggie fried rice was loaded with veggies that;s how it really should be  ,,, not bad all
author: NAEL K.

description: So, it's definitely not the most impressive place ever, but man I keep going back.  I actually like the service, there is a lady there that I totally love, she is super friendly and quick to help.  The food is decent and since it is right downstairs from my boyfriend's place, I can just go order it and get in like 15 minutes.  I kind of order boring things like Mongolian chicken, beef and broccoli and mushu chicken, but so far it's all pretty good.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
The food would be 3 stars, but the service is so homey and the free mimosas such a nice perk that I had to give +1 star.

The Chinese food is a lot better than American food.  Best to stick with the Chinese food.
author: John Paul M.

description: Add the eggplant tofu to your list of what to order... The orange chicken is pretty reliable but we had a bad batch last night. Goes well with cheap wine. One day I aspire to order at the counter... which is so very 1950s soda fountain...
author: Andrea D.

description: Dios Mio I think I found a very good Chinese Restaurant which is hard to find in the City even in Chinatown, but damn this rivals Lee's Chinese back in Ventura, I ordered the Sweet N Sour Chicken, with steamed rice & spring roll, & my brother who just had been recently tattooed ordered the Vegetarian plate with mushrooms, we also had sweet n sour soup with tofu. Great Place & will make this part of my regular weekend lineup.
author: Alberto L.

description: Fine, it's greasy Chinese, but it's exactly what you want when you want it. The orange chicken is yummmmmy...pot stickers too. And they'll make stuff up for you if you ask; what's not to like about the personal touch?
author: Arwen O.

description:
I'll just come out and say, I love Punjab.

Even though I don't get there as much as I would like to, there has never been a bad experience there. After visits 3 times a week for at least 4 months straight, they knew my name, what I ordered, and when I sent friends to eat there, they mentioned my name, and got the VIP treatment.

The food is always consistent, because the same head cooks are there all the time. The servers/owner are always very courteous, and love to make small talk and make you feel welcome. And the ambiance is amazing, huge restaurant, diner bar, top floor, and cafeteria style seating. Incredible.

I suggest getting a combo meal. #17 is by far my favorite. Salt and Pepper Fried Shrimp, no tails, and BBQ Pork Fried Rice. How much? 10 Bucks. 

I don't usually write Yelp reviews, I loathe it actually, but this restaurant needs business. Its great food, with truly great people running it. It would shame me to see such a diamond in the rough close, without so many people trying it.
author: eric e.

description: The nicest Chinese fam operates this place- love the grandma who always is smiling!  They are always so nice to us when we go in and serve us compliementary soup and always are very attentive!  I like their clean yummy food and great low prices!  So many people are scared of Chinese food but not to worry here- we go back again and again. Plus its so convenient being in the Mission on 24th St.
author: Sally W.

description: I gotta tell ya', this place is down to the bones good. Great place to bring kids- and a great place to just sit and eat and talk for hours. They were accommodating with my veggie needs and that of my family! I even brought my own soy chicken to have them cook up just to experiment and they were happy to do so. The people there are very friendly and Sweet. It feels like family there. My wife has been going there since she was a little girl and she gets treated just like one of the family. I met the staff just a little under a year ago, and they treated me just like one of them right off the top. Great place, good food, and relaxing environment. :)
author: Al N.

description: I was wary to try Punjab for Chinese because they boast serving Chinese and American food, so authenticity may be suspect.  I was also a little worried seeing Tapatio on the tables, rendering the food slightly Mexican in flavor in addition to being somewhere between Chinese and American.  The eggplant tofu dish was not too bad, if a little squishy and the crab rangoon were cute creamy pillows, as another reviewer stated.  Everything was incredibly greasy and bland, though.  The staff was friendly and very much wanted us to return, but I probably won't.
author: Jody S.

description:
won't deliver after she took my order for delivery: "no driver sorry, can you pick it up"!!!! what a lie! my order was $20 & I live 4 blocks away! 
NO THANK YOU!
author: Y B.

description: Punjab!!! I grew up two blocks away from this place, and apparently I was too young to pick out what I wanted, so my parents always got the same thing for me- chow mein with sweet&sour pork. Once I was old enough to choose, however, I went crazy haha. Punjab is very authentic and they have a good delivery service. The location is great and it's pretty clean inside too! I must go back there soon.
author: Chris N.

description: Half a block down from my house. I've only eaten here once. It was OK. The item I ordered was not what I expected, however it tasted fine.
author: Anita C.

description:
This is my local Chinese joint. Szechuan Chix, nice n' spicey. Good food, good price. Ain't the prettiest atmosphere, but us locals love it and they're good people. It is what it is... love it or leave it alone. 

**note: They've got an upper space where you can gather with family/ friends. No charge, just order a decent amount.
author: Dan J.

description: I love this restaurant and the servers are friendly. It is definitely old school Chinese restaurant and that is a good thing. Whenever I am in SF and in the Mission and in the mood for Chinese I come here. You cannot go wrong with the food and the prices are very reasonable. My friend who lives in SF has had banquets here several times.  The restaurant has a banquet room upstairs.  They always provide very delicious food, generous portions and friendly service.  Everyone is always pleased with the food.
author: M R.

description: a great spot in the mission to grab cheap, good food if you're feeling a bit burrito-weary. it's never crowded, the large portions are always hot and delicious. the wonton soup is full of wontons, the pot stickers have a perfect texture (not greasy and doughy like other inexpensive chinese places) and the vegetables are always cooked "wok mei". it looks like a family run place, everyone there is very nice and makes you feel at home. and amazingly, it seems to be invisible to all the annoying hipsters in the area (knock on wood).
author: cyrus t.

description:
YUMMY! All their food is delicious. Love their Felicias Combinations.Great specials. Not a big fan of their egg rolls though, sometimes they taste like they were frozen and their creme brulee cheescake tasted like the fridge smells when you leave food unwrapped BUT other than that everything else delicious.
Staff is very friendly EXCEPT for this one young thin chinese waitress that is sometimes rude.
One time me and my boyfriend went to eat there and we were ordering what we were going to eat there,as well as something to take home for dinner, so we wer ordering two of ea. item and when we were thinking of another item to go she says:"More? thats too much food, this enough ok." We were just like ok its your business we'll just get the fried rice and lemon chicken for here then.
I thought that was rude and stupid. But everythings good except for her attitude. Shes the reason they didnt get the 5 stars

PS:shes the one holding the plates in the 3rd pic.lol
author: Maria H.

description:
I want to tell everyone in SF how wonderful Punjab has been through my thirty years of great dining in this gem of a Mission restaurant.  Not only is the food very good, but the cooks, waitresses, and the fellow diners are the best!  What I really like is that Punjab is opened seven days a week.  When you become a regular customer it seems like you join another family-the Punjab family.
Felicia, the main cook, makes sure that all the ingredients are very fresh and as local as possible. The food is delicious and healthy. She is a friendly and caring woman.  Make sure you say hi to her. She doesn't get out onto the floor as often as she would like, because she is so busy in the kitchen.
BREAKFAST-What many people don't know is that Punjab serves breakfast every day.  You can have the best breakfast in the Mission starting at 11:00 A.M. on weekdays and 10:00 A.M. on weekends.
Punjab has an extensive menu with all the good dishes anyone would want for breakfast.  Felicia's  hash browns are great! I think her Hollandaise sauce is one of the best I have tasted. 
 Felicia is also a great gourmet chef. She can whip up braised lamb shanks, pork loin in lavender sauce, and fresh fish dishes.  She doesn't have these specials all the time, but if more of us come in requesting these and other gourmet specialties she will make them more often.  Ask for her avocado spring rolls with spicy plum sauce.
What is especially great is Felicia's Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners!  She makes a wonderful turkey dinner with all the other dishes we associate with the holidays.  Her Christmas dinner was to die for!  Her ham with a special sauce and scalloped potatoes was so good!   Punjab is also opened New Year's Day.
The staff is great.  Both of the waitresses, Judy and Serene, are sweet and will make your visit an enjoyable one.  Homg who makes most of the Chinese dishes is one great cook.
I hope after reading my review everyone will want to come to Punjab to have great meals and become one of our family.
author: cheryl b.

description: Good, cheap food in what appears to be an old diner.  The folks that work there are super nice.
author: Irene M.

description: mediocre vegetable fried rice with fried tofu.  probably will not go here again.  veggies did not seem fresh and the rice was not very flavorful.   i chose if for convenience, but i'd rather have joe's excellent chinese on ocean blvd.
author: Melissa B.

description: Ordered some hot & sour soup, beef chow fun, and egg rolls. Took about half an hour for delivery. Food came HOT! The chow fun is great, didn't have to use any of the soy sauce they give you. Also like the fact they use a lot of beans spouts. I love bean sprouts. Egg rolls are great. They were nice and crispy. My guess is that they are made to order. Hot & Sour soup was good. Can't really compare it to anything as this is my first time tasting it. This was my first time ordering from them and not my last!
author: David S.

description: I don't know this place but I find it odd that a Chinese eatery is called "Punjab".  Is it some sort of snafu in the yelp database ??
author: C A.

description:
Punjab is a great Chinese restaurant in the heart of the up & coming "Mission". This neighborhood place has been around for generations. I've been going for years.  Believe me, it's not a trendy kind of place but where they lack in ambience and service, they make up by serving delicious fare at decent prices. I stand by that old phrase "you get what you pay for". Punjab really meets up to my expectations. With today's unstable economy, who's not looking for a bargain? One can easily feed a family of 4 for less than 25.00 or go with bunch of friends for Tsing Tao beers and sample the tasty appetizers. I love hot and spicy and here are some of my favorites.
Singapore Rice Noodles - Spicy curried rice vermecilli stir fried with bbq pork, shrimp, bell peppers, scallions, bean sprouts and egg.
Mongolian Beef - tender slices of flank steak with julienned strips of red and green bell peppers, carrots, onions, scallions, bamboo shoots in dark spicy brown sauce. (I like this extra hot)
Pork or Chicken Potstickers - Homemade meat dumplings with minced garlic, ginger and cilantro lightly pan fried with house made chili dipping sauce.
Korean Chicken -Deep fried battered chicken drumettes served with a tangy hot & spicy sauce. (I always order these and they are the first to go!) 
Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings - Lightly battered deep fried chicken wings tossed in a spicy mixture with jalapenos, bell peppers and onions.
Wonton Soup - After a night on the town, I love to have a steamy bowl of freshly made wonton soup with spicy oil.
Punjab also makes great vegetarian stir fry. I love the Mixed Vegetable with Tofu or the Black Mushroom with Baby Bok Choy.  The fresh Long Bean or Snow Peas in Garlic Sauced is a must. You can also order that spicy. 
Check out Felcia's Combo Plates.
I encourage you to visit Punjab's for its no frills simple tasty food at reasonable prices.
If you want fancy, go to Great Eastern or Koi Palace
author: James W.
